addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

8 Au
g
1592. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
His proceedinges in the Cawse of
Collonell Senoye
./

page.lettertext:
fol.165r
May it please yo
r
good L. wheras her
Ma
tie
hath
eftsoons written in
e cause of Coronel Sonoy, and yo
r
L. in yo
r
last
at concerned his affaires, required
me to bring it to some finall conclusion: I have
done in
at respect for
e Coronels advantage what
was possible for me. But for as muche as his de-
maundes are not all of one q
a
litie, and this people
most unwilling to shewe him any kinde of favo
r
,
I have bin forced for his benefit to temporise in my
dealing, to solicit men in privat, to part his suite
into divers motions, and to observe some other courses,
w
ch
those
at are his facto
rs
did thinke behoofull to
continue. For this occasion I could not write
yo
w
, any resolut answear about his buisnes, and to
put yo
w
to
e trouble of understanding all
e causes,
of those delaies
at were used, considering M
r
Sonoy
was well informed by his frindes, I thought it not
convenient. But nowe that all is effected, that
I am able to obtene, it may please yo
r
L. to be cer-
tified, that maters stande in these terms, That of
the Coronels whole demaunde, amounting almost
to 5000
li
sterling, there is onely paied unto him
80
li
for certaine gonnepowder, w
ch
he had left of his
owne in
e towne of
Medenblike:
and 500
li
ster-
ling more, for
at he was indebted to
e inhabit
a
ts
of
e towne, w
ch
I have gotte to be discharged. But
wholy against
e heare, and w
t
very muche con-
tention in my conference w
t
them. And for
at
w
ch
is remaining of
e summe afore mentioned, w
ch
is due for arrierages of divers intertenments, I
can gette no other answear, albeit I have used very
speciall endevo
rs
, but
at he shall be so considered
fol.165v
as the rest of their creditors: w
ch
is so sette downe
at length, in their booke of resolutions, wherof they have
sent me an autentical extract, and
e transcript
in Frenche shall be joined w
t
this letter, as I have also
sent a copie to
e Coronel himself. But all their
answear in
at behalf is no better in effect then a
cunning denial. For if they were inclined to any
equitie in his suite, they knowe his case doth differ
muche, from
e most of
e rest, to whome
e contrey
is indebted. For when they made their composition,
he was actual gouverno
r
of
e towne of Meden-
blike, and they contracted plainely w
t
him,
at ether
he should continue as gouverno
r
in
e place, or have an
honorable
discharge, and contentment w
t
reason for all his ser-
vices forepast. Wherupon I have insisted, that al-
though they doe pretend
e want of meanes and abi-
litie to pay
e summes
at he demaundes, yet it is a
mater in their power, and a part of their couven
a
t,
to restoare him to his gouvernment. The replie
that they make is but a dallieng abuse, by perver-
ting
e sense of a plaine composition. For they say
they are but bounde, to content him w
t
reason: and
they thinke he ought to take it for a reasonable con-
tentment, in
at they promise to intreat him, as the
rest of their creditors. W
ch
in effect is no better, but
presently to leese
e benefit of his gouvernment, and
to have as muche as nothing, for his recompense heere-
after: and so I have not failed to lette them under-
tand. But to impart to yo
r
L. my privat
conceat, though they themselves will not signifie
e
mysterie of their meaning in this twart kinde of
d ealing, yet they make it very manifest by the
course of their doinges, and by
e cleerenes of their
fol.166r
speeches in
e causes of some others. For thus they
are persuaded, and nothing can be said,
at will
dissuade them from it, That when my
L. of Lei-
cester
was chosen to this gouvernment, he had a
present intention, to make a conquest of
e contrey,
and
at divers suche as M
r
Sonoy did not onely w
at
they could to second his designes, but were
e princi-
pall plotters of those intended alterations,
at were
essaied in divers townes. And this opinion of
their disloialtie is rooted so deepely in a nomber
of this nation,
at though they
seeme
had for
in open shewe, not
to seeke to revenge it, they will grieve
e parties
underhand, by all
e meanes they can devise.
Of
e occurrences at
e Campe, I can
not being heere make a perfitte report: and because
I doe attend upon her Ma
ties
pleasure, about
e sending
for
e companies, I can not as I would conveni
e
tly
goe thither. For
e states residing heere, w
t
whome
I must negotiat in affaires of
at nature, if I
should be at
e campe, w
t
e bringing thither of
my letters, and my returning hither againe, there
would be peradventure a greater losse of time
then her Ma
tie
would like. Touching
that w
ch
was advertised from
e
Councel of Estate
,
that certaine forces of
e enemie were marched out
of
Brabant,
and passed
e Maese, I knowe not
where upon it came, but they speake no more of
it. For w
ch
the Englishe companies continue still
in garrison, and
Count Maurice
proceedeth in
e
siege of
Coevoerden:
having gained already
e
bourgh before
e castell, and beaten downe a great
part of
e castel it self: whereby his hope is er
fol.166v
be long to bring
at woorke unto an end.
Upon secret intelligence from certaine in
Groeninghen,
that sins
stenwicke
was taken
e chief w
t
in
e towne
are devided among themselves, of w
ch
some are desi-
rous to treat w
t
these contreis, upon hope of obtening
more eq
a
l conditions,
e
states
have written to
e towne
a very kinde letter, w
ch
is sent by a trumpet from
the campe, whose returne is expected w
t
in five or six
daies.
And thus I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. Au
g
8 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
